oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Baptist Church, East Thomas: front view
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 419 11th Court West, Birmingham, Jefferson County, AL

Black and white photograph of the front (north) facade of a brick church with two towers of unequal height that are defined by a slight projection from the facade and are topped by low angled pyramidal roofs. A covered terrace outside the double entrance doors is covered by a flat metal canopy. Windows at the base of each tower and above the entrance of of painted glass. The residential setting of the church can be seen.

First Baptist Church in the East Thomas neighborhood of Birmingham was organized in 1938 and the Gothic-style brick church with twin towers was constructed the following year. The church supported the Alabama Christian Movement for Civil Rights (AMCHR) during the civile rights era by hosting mass meetings and serving as a strategy center. It also participated in the 1963 Project C demonstration, during which the Reverend J.A. Hayes and other prominent ministers were arrested for violating a city ordinance and a court injunction against street demonstrations. This case developed into the landmark Supreme Court ruling of Shuttlesworth v. Birmingham (1969).
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee
Churches
